bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Henry E. Sigerist, January 22, 1941

div1.p: Hench thanks Sigerist for his offer to publish his paper on yellow fever in the Johns Hopkins "Bulletin of the History of Medicine."

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Henry E. Sigerist, January 22, 1941
div1.opener:
January 22, 1941
Dr. Henry E. Sigerist
Johns Hopkins University
Institute of the History of Medicine
1900 East Monument Street
Baltimore, Maryland
My dear Doctor Sigerist:
div1.p:
I appreciated your letter of a couple of weeks ago, offering
the pages of your Bulletin of the History of Medicine to my paper on yellow fever,
and the reason I have not written you sooner is that I have been trying to decide
in my own mind how to answer your gracious letter.

By separate post, I am sending you a brochure which includes an
abstract of a talk which I gave at the dedication of the Lazear Memorial Building
at Washington and Jefferson College. I did not know they were publishing this
talk as they specifically said they were not, and that I could use it, as I pre-
ferred to do, for publication in a medical journal. I did not see proof; hence,
the two or three errors.

I have spent three years in this investigation and have accumulated
a great amount of unpublished data. Until recently I hadn't the slightest desire
to earn any money out of this investigation but now, having found the remains of
Camp Lazear and the remains of the famous Infected Clothing Building (Building No. 1)
and having arranged to purchase it, I have taken upon myself the job of raising
money to restore the building and if possible, build a little memorial building
around it so that it can be preserved for posterity. For this reason alone I
hope to be able to raise some money somewhere, somehow, from interested friends
and some institutions with which Reed and Lazear were connected. If I should fail
in collecting the money from friends, with this in mind I hope I might get enough
returns from a monograph to at least start the ball rolling.

I have four papers now available for publication:
1. The amplified, corrected address as given in the Washington
and Jefferson brochure. (This certainly should be made available to medical
readers and should not be wasted on what is essentially a college advertisement.)
2. After much work I have got Kissinger to write out his story
for me. It needed much correction and editing, and I have about finished this.
Neither he nor Moran, the first ones who volunteered to Reed for experimentation
have ever published their story.
Dr. Henry E. Sigerist
- 2 -
January 22, 1941
3. I have also done the same thing with Moran's story and
have promised both Kissinger and Moran to publish their own stories under their
own names, with perhaps an editorial foreword by myself.
4. I am now writing at the request of the Minister of
National Defense of the Cuban government, a documentary report on the true
identity of Camp Lazear and the building which we discovered. A so-called
“Camp Lazear” which the Cuban government has bought and memorialized by fence
and sign and for the memorialization of which they have collected $200,000
is the wrong place. Whether the Cubans accept my documentation or not, this
same report, rewritten for a medical journal, should be made available for
the medical public.

I have been wondering whether I should publish these four
separately or save them all for a monograph, rather profusely illustrated with
maps and other unpublished photographs which I have collected. The advantage
of a monograph is that it might bring me in a few hundred dollars for the sake
of my plane.

I should greatly appreciate your comments and advice. I believe
on occasion your journal has published papers and later republished them as a
monograph. Perhaps some such scheme could be worked out with these. Incidentally,
General Truby is preparing his autobiography. I fear it may be too long for any
one medical journal but as he has asked for my help and suggestions regarding his
autobiography, I would appreciate knowing what the approximate length of any
papers are that you publish and whether you would be interested in seeing his
autobiography. He was commanding officer of Columbia Barracks where Reed and
the other members of the Board planned all of their work. As such, he was
intimately associated with all the work.
div1.closer: Very truly yours, P. S. Hench, M. D. psh:ds
